L1.brief_rationale: The broad discipline studying production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services; universally recognized as a social science.
Economic system based on private ownership and free markets; widely understood from everyday political and social discourse.
Economic system emphasizing collective or state ownership; recognized globally as a major alternative to capitalism.
Exchange of goods and services across national borders; universally familiar from news about imports, exports, and tariffs.
State of lacking sufficient material resources; universally recognized human condition central to development economics.
Unequal distribution of income and assets across a population; widely discussed in public policy and media.
Increasing interconnectedness of world economies through trade, investment, and technology; universally recognized from everyday experience.
Author of The Wealth of Nations and founder of classical economics; recognized by general audiences as the father of modern economics.
Policy of minimal government restrictions on international commerce; widely understood from public debate over tariffs and trade agreements.
Process by which nations improve economic well-being and quality of life; universally discussed in the context of developing countries.
Lowest legally mandated wage employers may pay; universally recognized from labor policy debates in virtually every country.
Severe worldwide economic downturn of the 1930s; universally known historical event that shaped modern economic policy.
Systematic process for comparing the costs and benefits of a decision; widely used and understood across business, government, and everyday life.

L2.brief_rationale: Field integrating psychology with economic decision-making to explain irrational behavior; widely taught at the undergraduate level.
Study of labor markets, wage determination, and employment dynamics; a core cross-cutting subfield taught in undergraduate economics programs.
Application of statistical and mathematical methods to economic data; a foundational methodology course in every economics degree.
School of thought emphasizing aggregate demand and government intervention; a central framework studied in undergraduate economics.
Government-imposed restrictions on international trade such as tariffs and quotas; standard topic in international economics courses.
Economic value of a worker's skills and knowledge; widely taught concept connecting education, training, and economic productivity.
Statistical measure of income or wealth inequality within a population; standard metric taught in development and welfare economics courses.
School of thought from Smith, Ricardo, and Mill emphasizing free markets and the labor theory of value; foundational to the history of economic thought.
Kahneman and Tversky's model describing how people evaluate gains and losses asymmetrically; cornerstone of behavioral economics taught at the undergraduate level.
Study of economic effects of environmental policies and natural resource use; a growing subfield taught in undergraduate programs.
Statistical method for estimating relationships among variables; the primary empirical tool in undergraduate econometrics.
Ratio of export prices to import prices measuring a country's trading position; standard concept in international economics courses.
Economic system combining private enterprise with government intervention; widely taught as the most common real-world economic organization.

L3.brief_rationale: Study of how institutions such as laws, norms, and organizations shape economic behavior; requires professional-level understanding of economic systems beyond standard models.
Application of economic methods to health care markets and policy; a specialized applied field requiring professional knowledge of both economics and health systems.
Application of economic reasoning to political decision-making and government behavior; requires working knowledge of rent-seeking, voting models, and bureaucratic incentives.
Use of controlled laboratory experiments to test economic theories; requires professional familiarity with experimental design, incentive compatibility, and replication standards.
Trade model predicting patterns based on countries' relative factor endowments; requires professional-level understanding of factor proportions theory and its empirical tests.
Econometric technique addressing endogeneity by using external instruments; requires working knowledge of two-stage least squares and identification conditions.
Graphical representation of income or wealth distribution used to derive the Gini coefficient; requires professional knowledge of distributional analysis.
Theorem linking trade liberalization to changes in factor returns; requires working knowledge of the Heckscher-Ohlin framework and its distributional implications.
Heterodox school emphasizing spontaneous order, subjective value, and entrepreneurship; requires professional knowledge of the history of economic thought and methodological debates.
Balassa's index measuring a country's export specialization relative to the world; requires working knowledge of trade data analysis and competitiveness measurement.
Survey-based technique for valuing non-market goods like environmental amenities; requires professional familiarity with willingness-to-pay methods and their limitations.
Quasi-experimental method comparing treatment and control groups over time; a core causal-inference technique requiring professional-level econometric knowledge.

L4.brief_rationale: Mathematical framework proving existence and properties of economy-wide equilibrium via fixed-point theorems; requires deep knowledge of Arrow-Debreu models and welfare theorems.
Formal study of aggregating individual preferences into collective decisions; requires expert knowledge of impossibility results, voting rules, and welfare functions.
Numerical simulation models of entire economies calibrated to real data; requires specialist knowledge of calibration, SAM construction, and policy counterfactuals.
Empirical model predicting bilateral trade flows from economic size and distance; requires expert knowledge of its theoretical micro-foundations and estimation with multilateral resistance.
Two-step procedure correcting sample selection bias in econometric models; requires deep knowledge of the inverse Mills ratio, maximum likelihood estimation, and identification assumptions.
Frameworks for analyzing stable allocations in two-sided markets; requires expert knowledge of Gale-Shapley deferred acceptance, stability conditions, and market design applications.
Framework analyzing transaction costs, property rights, and governance structures in economic organization; requires deep knowledge of Coase, Williamson, and North's contributions.
Causal inference method exploiting threshold-based treatment assignment; requires expert knowledge of bandwidth selection, local polynomial estimation, and validity checks.
Sen and Nussbaum's framework evaluating development by people's freedoms and capabilities rather than income alone; requires deep knowledge of welfare economics and development theory.

Theory of designing tax systems to maximize social welfare subject to incentive constraints; requires expert knowledge of Mirrlees and Ramsey models, equity-efficiency tradeoffs, and sufficient statistics.
Causal inference technique constructing a counterfactual from weighted comparison units; requires specialist knowledge of donor pool selection, pre-treatment fit, and inference via permutation.

Reverse game theory designing rules to achieve desired outcomes under private information; requires expert knowledge of incentive compatibility, revelation principle, and implementation theory applied to economic institutions.
